channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Q3 2020 Recap
item.description: Professional golf has been underway for months with only minor testing headaches, while the pandemic-era versions of the Tour de France, the U.S. Open in tennis, and the Kentucky Derby went off smoothly. If the first two quarters of the year meant us coming to terms with a global pandemic, Q3 saw us settling into a ~new normal~ of face masks, parking lot dining, and saying "whoops, sorry!"   So what about K-12?   Q3 was the busiest for public offerings since the dot-com era.   That was a lot.   The election, for one.   Over the last three months, extreme weather events made more intense and frequent by human-induced climate change have ravaged communities across the country. There's actually good news.   Pulse check on the economic recovery  It's...   So why are biz leaders wearing out DocuSign?   Looking ahead On the monetary side...   On the corporate side...   On the fiscal side...   Looking ahead... School Reopenings Test Students, College Towns, and Parents After schools across the country closed their doors in the spring, John Krasinski hosted virtual prom, graduation ceremonies were streamed online, and at least one student accidentally said, “Sup, b****?”   Soccer: A  This summer, the National Women's Soccer League became the first major U.S. sports league to return to action from the Covid break, while the MLS has already welcomed fans back in certain states.    How the Economic Recovery Fared in Q3 As the ink dries on Q3, nearly 900,000 Americans are filing new jobless claims each week.   The Atlantic Coast produced so many big tropical storms that the World Meteorological Organization depleted its list of 21 names by September and is now using the Greek alphabet. Even where students can attend school, many parents have chosen not to enroll them. University of Iowa students angered Twitter (an easy feat, really) by lining up for downtown bars in Iowa City, which earlier this month had the fourth-highest Covid-19 cases per capita in the U.S. But for local businesses like The Airliner bar, students returning to campus is their only lifeline—revenue was $0 in April.   Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times via Getty Images Parts of the West Coast have been ablaze since August, with a record 3.7 million acres burned across California. Climate change is no longer one of those problems. the M&A could keep flowing, but experts think the IPO frenzy will settle by late October.   Whether you want to relive summer 2020 or would rather pretend it never happened, we present: the Brew's third quarter recap. Basketball: A+  Zero NBA players have tested positive for Covid-19 since entering the famous "bubble" in Orlando. The Tampa Bay Rays, the Brew’s July pick to win it all, entered the postseason as the top team in the American League. But with the election and a Supreme Court fight ahead, don't hold your breath for more emergency aid until the Christmas lights come out.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Uber Sells Self-Driving Division to Aurora Innovations
item.description: Uber is reportedly unloading its air taxi division too.   Why Uber is letting go:  Self-driving cars are expensive.   Who is Aurora? Uber hasn’t completely given up on AVs—it’ll eventually use Aurora's self-driving cars.   Big picture: Several self-driving startups have downsized or closed shop during the pandemic. Subscribe to Emerging Tech Brew.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Bob Dylan Sells Songwriting Catalog to the Universal Music Publishing Group in Historic Deal
item.description: Yesterday, cultural icon/harmonica player Bob Dylan sold his entire catalog of more than 600+ songs to the Universal Music Publishing Group. Why it matters: Dylan is one of the most famous artists of all time, and his catalog is considered a priceless treasure of the music canon.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: China Trade Surplus Reaches Highest Level Ever
item.description: In November, China posted its biggest month for exports on record, and its trade surplus—the amount by which exports exceed imports—topped $75 billion.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: California Water Futures are First to Trade on Chicago Mercantile Exchange
item.description: If you buy a futures contract, you agree to purchase the asset at a predetermined price on a future date.   California farmers could use the help California is the country's largest water market by a magnitude of four, but the quality of its water supply is less consistent than a container of strawberries in January. Investors can buy futures contracts for everything from fresh bacon to Burgundy wine, but the commoditization of an element critical to daily life is worrying to some observers—especially as water access becomes more strained."
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Ikea to Stop Making Iconic Catalog After this Year
item.description: Bottom line: Online furniture sales have been a pandemic winner for retailers like Wayfair and Amazon, so Ikea's decision to focus on its digital operations makes business sense.   + While we're here: If you're feeling nostalgic, visit the digital Ikea museum to leaf through decades of past catalog issues.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: The Week Ahead: Airbnb's IPO and Congressional Compromises
item.description: Hanukkah starts at sundown on Thursday.   Everything else:  Today is the anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941. The videogame Cyberpunk 2077 will be released on Thursday after several delays and an astronomical budget.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Coastal Carolina vs. BYU Arranged at Last Minute
item.description: These two teams were not supposed to play one another.   And the game itself was thrilling—Coastal Carolina eked out a win that came down to the last play.    A few days ago, the NBA released only half of its regular-season schedule to give itself the wiggle room the NFL wishes it had. Mullets.”
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Metals Prices Surge as Manufacturing Kicks into High Gear
item.description: Plus, the U.S. and China’s geopolitical game of chicken led to uncertainty for mining companies, which slowed investment in new mines from 2016 on.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: New California Covid-19 Restrictions Face Pushback From Small Businesses
item.description: Bottom line: California leaders are struggling to address the growing public health crisis (LA County hit a record number of cases four times last week) and simmering anger from devastated small businesses.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Western Countries Will Likely Administer the First Covid-19 Vaccines This Week
item.description: Russia began inoculating its citizens on Saturday with its Sputnik V vaccine, and about 1 million Chinese people have already been vaccinated.    In further defense of the FDA’s process, last week the U.S.’ top infectious disease official, Dr. Anthony Fauci, called the UK ruling “rushed,” which ticked off some British health officials.   The debate over timing On Thursday, the FDA is expected to vote on approving the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for emergency use, and it could be administered to Americans the next day.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Metals Prices Surge as Manufacturing Kicks into High Gear
item.description: Put your microeconomic hat on The U.S. and China’s geopolitical game of chicken led to uncertainty for mining companies, which slowed investment in new mines from 2016 on.

item.title: Western Countries Will Likely Administer the First Covid-19 Vaccines This Week
item.description: Russia began inoculating its citizens on Saturday with its Sputnik V vaccine, and about 1 million Chinese people have already been vaccinated.    In further defense of the FDA’s process, last week the U.S.’ top infectious disease official, Dr. Anthony Fauci, called the UK ruling “rushed,” which ticked off some British health officials.   The debate over timing On Thursday, the FDA is expected to vote on approving the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for emergency use, and it could be administered to Americans the next day.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Data Warehousing Company Snowflake is Now a $100 Billion Giant
item.description: Bottom line: While Snowflake’s value has more than tripled since its public debut this fall, Wall Street is recommending investors break out the snow tires—more than half of the 22 analysts covering the company say it’s a “Hold” at this time.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Disappointing Jobs Report May Increase Chances of Stimulus Deal
item.description: The restaurant industry lost jobs for the first time since April.   9.8 million fewer Americans remain employed than before the pandemic.   Looking ahead... So, like any astute economic observers, we expected stocks to fall and Treasury prices to rise (Treasuries are considered a safe haven for investors when the economic outlook goes south). The U.S. economy added 245,000 jobs last month, a reading below expectations and less than half of the 610,000 job gains in October. The weekend is shaping up to be an eventful one in D.C.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Ryan’s World Will Soon be a Virtual Theme Park In Roblox
item.description: The park will feature a racetrack, school, city center, and an obstacle course-filled “fun zone,” where players can walk among characters from Ryan’s show and, occasionally, with Ryan himself.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: The McRib’s Many Economic Conspiracy Theories
item.description: Companies choose to take an L on these items in the hopes that it will lure customers to buy profitable products that recoup the loss.   While there’s no direct link between McRib rollouts and the Mayan calendar, there are a few popular conspiracy theories detailed by Willy Staley in The Awl purporting to explain why the McRib occasionally rises from the fast food ashes... Theory #1: Porky arbitrage   Axios Does McDonald’s time McRib releases to the pork price cycle for a bigger profit per sandwich?   If McRibs were as popular as McNuggets, it’s feasible they’d also become a forever menu item and the pork industry would play catch-up like chicken had. Eventually, the chicken supply caught up to McDonald’s demand, while the McRib’s popularity waned. + This theory could tie back to the first one: If the McRib is indeed a loss leader, McDonald’s would have more reason to take advantage of low pork prices.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Data Warehousing Company Snowflake is Now a $100 Billion Giant
item.description: Bottom line: While Snowflake’s value has more than tripled since its public debut this fall, Wall Street is recommending investors break out the snow tires—more than half of the 22 analysts covering the company say it’s a “Hold” at this time.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Pet Retailer Petco Files to Go Public
item.description: Petco, which has 1,470 physical retail locations, also invested $300 million into its e-commerce and digital operations to capitalize on that growing trend.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: U.S. House Votes to Legalize Marijuana
item.description: The bill, called the MORE Act, would remove pot from the Controlled Substances Act and also expunge some marijuana-related convictions. Yesterday, the U.S. House passed a landmark bill that would decriminalize marijuana at the federal level.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Special Report: How Vaccines Are Made
item.description: Getting in Line for a Vaccine Like   Giphy Reality check: There won't be enough Covid-19 vaccines for everyone for a while. $21—the difference in price between Moderna's vaccine ($25/dose) and AstraZeneca's vaccine ($4/dose), according to U.S. purchase agreements.   Vaccine candidates 67 vaccine candidates are currently in various stages of clinical trials around the world.   10 billion single doses could be available by the end of 2022 if all the frontrunner vaccine candidates are approved.   But not so fast: Moderna's vaccine requires two doses 28 days apart.   Once We Have a Vaccine...   Let's Hit the Road  We just spit a lot of information at you about the vaccine supply chain. #3: Not everyone will get a vaccine.   Let’s set the mood with this passage from The Economist:  “Deliverance, when it arrives, will come in a small glass vial.   Who next?   The early leaders? How the Magic Happens   Francis Scialabba Maybe Thanksgiving is getting us sentimental, but the concept of a vaccine is kind of...   The next round of Phase 1 will include other vulnerable groups such as...   Vaccine manufacturing is Isla de Muerta  It's an island that cannot be found, except by those who already know where it is.   Pharma Companies Channel Their Inner Elsa   Giphy Leading vaccine candidates are more temperature-sensitive than your dad who doesn't let anyone touch the thermostat. But can employers legally require their workers to get vaccines? The Duke Global Health Institute estimates 9.6 billion doses are already reserved by individual countries, without any vaccines having reached the market yet.   Zoom out: The companies currently vying to get a Covid-19 vaccine to market are pursuing different biological methods, in the hopes that a "throw everything against the wall" approach will lead to a few sticking.       Economist That's a bit lopsided Which is where Covax comes in. Distribution 8,000 fully filled 747 cargo planes would be needed to distribute a single vaccine dose to the world's 7.8 billion people, per the International Air Transportation Association. The total costs of vaccine development can run up to $500 million, one study found. We'll walk through everything from how a vaccine is made to who gets the first shot to whether your boss can force you to get one.   Storage is tight. Establishing public trust in these vaccines will be the next major challenge for health officials. Where do vaccines come from?   Short answer: Yes.*  *There are exceptions for people with disabilities or those with "sincerely held" religious beliefs against vaccination.   Big picture: The Duke Global Health Institute thinks it'll take until 2024 for vaccines to reach the entire population. Probably not, but Pfizer does.   Did you know there's currently a shortage of sand needed to make glass vials for vaccine storage?   Plus, it's not cheap. With an $18+ billion budget ($12+ million of which has already been doled out), the goal is to deliver 300 million doses of a safe and effective vaccine by Jan. 2021.   Then, they're on the road, this time to a regional distribution center.   Methodologies vary, but the overall breakdown goes something like this:  Step 1: Create an antigen (a substance that provokes your immune system).   Dry ice is the cold chain's best friend.   How it works: There are 184 countries participating, with wealthier countries subsidizing vaccine access for 92 lower- and middle-income ones, particularly across Africa and South and Southeast Asia. In a November Gallup poll, 42% of U.S. adults said they would not get an FDA-approved coronavirus vaccine. The vaccine will head to an administration site like a mobile clinic or a Costco, where injectees will get a shot, a chicken bake, six gallons of salsa, and be on their way.
item.author: Morning Brew

item.title: Brew Crossword: Musical Dogposers
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: OPEC+ Compromises on January Oil Production Hike
item.description: August: The group eased cuts to 7.7 million/day.   May: OPEC+ decided to cut output by 9.7 million barrels/day to prop up prices.     What’s OPEC+? In all, big oil companies have written down ~$80 billion in assets this year, Reuters reports. Yesterday, Chevron shaved up to $6 billion off its budget.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: California Implements New Round of Strict Covid-19 Restrictions
item.description: Zoom out: You can lead a horse to water, but it’s trickier to make it stay indoors—the growing infection numbers suggest Californians are getting weary of Covid-19 restrictions.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: BlackRock Alums Named to Biden’s Cabinet Generate Controversy
item.description: Yesterday, President-elect Joe Biden named Brian Deese, head of sustainable investing at asset manager BlackRock, to helm the National Economic Council (NEC).   Deese worked at the NEC under former President Obama, where he helped form the auto bailout of 2008.     The Brooks Brothers crowd is even more pleased.   What it means: The clipboard crowd isn’t happy.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Warner Bros. to Release 2021 Films in Theaters and on HBO Max
item.description: , a subsidiary of AT&T's WarnerMedia, said it will release its 2021 movies on AT&T's streaming service, HBO Max, at the same time they debut in theaters. In an announcement that shook the film industry, Warner Bros.   After 31 days on HBO Max, movies will be exclusive to theaters until they ship out to a Roku near you.   Theaters are losing hope for a Christmas miracle AMC stock fell 16% and Cinemark's 22% following the news, capping off a devastating nine-month streak for theater chains.   Warner Bros.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: The Brew’s Weekly News Quiz: December 4
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Small Company, Big Moves: A Guide to Disruptive Investing
item.description: And as more and more of these organizations look to IPO or woo investors, learning what to look for can be the difference between spotting a unicorn and riding something into the ground.   It may be more important to focus on companies who are disrupting industries that will be around for the long haul.   So we asked our investing friends at The Motley Fool to help us know what to look for before we get disruptive with our investing. Join Stock Advisor today to get your hands on these new picks. If this seems far-fetched, take a moment to consider what you think it would actually take for a company to achieve such lofty goals.
item.author: Morning Brew

item.title: Apple, Spotify, and TikTok Release Their Year-End-Roundups
item.description: the global pandemic simulator Plague Inc. came in at No. 2 on the paid gaming charts. Spotify. App Store: Unsurprisingly, Zoom was the most downloaded free app of the year, with TikTok and Disney+ following closely behind.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: This Year’s Largest Acquisition? It’s Not What You Think
item.description: Bottom line: The former NYC mayor and memelord’s namesake company still towers over the financial data market.   Intercontinental Exchange, LSE rival and owner of the NYSE, has bought both mortgage finance tech platform Ellie Mae and data provider Interactive Data in the past few years.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Discovery Inc. Launches Streaming Service
item.description: It’s also partnering with Verizon to give 55 million customers one year of Discovery+ for free, a similar strategy to the Disney+ debut. It’s going big Discovery is offering 55,000 episodes from 2,500 different shows upon launch, the most content of any new streaming service.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Coronavirus Aid: Democratic Leaders Back Compromise Bill
item.description: But there’s been some movement. Democratic Sen. Mark Warner told NBC that failing to pass a relief bill before Congress breaks for the holidays would be “stupidity on steroids.” Bottom line: Momentum has been building in the past few days, but time is extremely running out.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: E-Commerce Boom Strains Delivery Networks
item.description: Follow the money  The investors with the biggest pockets are making bets on the physical infrastructure that powers e-commerce: warehouses.      Bottom line: With consumers feeling more comfortable shopping online and companies rapidly expanding their e-commerce infrastructure, the retail industry has been catapulted years into the future by the pandemic.   Shopify, a platform that’s home to 1+ million merchants, reported that Black Friday sales increased 75% annually to $2.4 billion, per Retail Brew. U.S. store visits dropped more than 50% on Black Friday from last year.
item.author: Neal Freyman
